paragraphs.text: Will the awful power of the word 'slut' defeat feminists' efforts to reclaim it?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: It's been over twenty years since then
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Bikini Kill frontwoman and Riot Grrrl icon Kathleen Hanna scrawled the word SLUT across her stomach
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In the years since, there's been a book called Slut!
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: , countless feminist debates over the reclamation of the word "slut" and, in 2011, thousands of women took to streets across the globe in anti-rape marches called SlutWalks - a reference to how victims of sexual assault are often blamed for the violence done to them
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Like "cunt" and "bitch", many feminists have long tried to wrest away from its original users the power and harm of the word "slut" and to give it new meaning
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Increasingly, though, it's seeming like we might not succeed any time soon
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Take Leora Tanenbaum: in 2000, she wrote Slut!: Growing up Female with a Bad Reputation chronicling girls' and women's experiences with the word
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: She herself was called a "slut" as a high school student in the 1980s
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: long before the term "sexual harassment" was coined - and told me"I had no vocabulary to understand what happened."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Now, 15 years later, Tanenbaum is about to publish another book: I Am Not a Slut
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because, in part, the sheen of reclaiming "slut" seems to have worn off over the years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When she spoke to women who called themselves "sluts" with a "positive and defiant" spirit, all told her the decision had turned against them later- and all regretted it
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Tanenbaum told me that, when women are in closed circle or close-knit community - like a protest with like-minded people, or among friends who understand the cheeky appropriation of the word - identifying as a "slut" can be empowering
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what inevitably happens, especially in today's digital culture where revenge porn, stolen pictures and cyber harassment is the norm, is that "it always spills outwards."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: For them it was an amazing feminist experience
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it didn't last
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Every single person I spoke to who intentionally embraced a "slut" persona ended up being treated terribly by people outside of her circle
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because the culture we live in is so dominated by the sexual double standard
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But beyond women who tried to reclaim "slut" for themselves, other feminists have rightfully asked why we should all try to reclaim a word with so much baggage - especially a word that impacts different women differently, and brings them a lot more pain than righteous justice
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: SlutWalks, for example, are no longer the cause celebre they once were
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because some women of color spoke out against the ways in which the protests and the reclamation of "slut" focused on the ability of white women to simultaneously embrace the word and reject its meaning
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: A group of black female academics, activists, and writers wrote an open letter explaining that "as Black women, we do not have the privilege or the space to call ourselves 'slut' without validating the already historically entrenched ideology and recurring messages about what and who the Black woman is."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Rutgers professor and writer Brittney Cooper wrote at the time,"To organize a movement around the reclamation of a term is in and of itself an act of white privilege."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In response, some SlutWalk organizers changed the name of their protests
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: today
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a handful of SlutWalks remain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the excitement over the movement has waned noticeably
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But women everywhere are still being actively, physically hurt by the stereotypes that lead people to call them "sluts"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Just look to the high profile deaths of young women who were slut-shamed and a mass shooting where the killer said he was targeting "blonde sluts"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we're still being targeted because of our identities and sexualities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it has, perhaps appropriately, put a damper on the once-celebratory reclamation of the word
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Maybe that the wounds inflicted by "slut"- and the culture that encourages people to define women that way - that we once hoped were superficial are just too raw and too deep
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Maybe the speed of the internet is too fast for us to control a word with so much potential to damage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There' s a poster on my living room wall by artist Favianna Rodriguez that reads:"I'm a Slut. I Vote. So Does Everyone I Sleep With. And You're About to be More Fucked Than I Am."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: For me, it captures the brash, in-your-face spirit that the feminist movement I've loved is known for
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But in this time of unprecedented feminist power, the conversation about "slut" can be more reflective than fevered
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Women who want to call themselves "sluts" shouldn't stop, or be made to stop
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I love that women can embrace that which is meant to hurt them and find power in it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But I also know that we can still claim our sexuality and agency without using a word meant to denigrate- a word that still hurts so many people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Besides
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we don't need "slut" to tell us what we already know: women have sex
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: some people don't like that and we're going to continue to do it anyway
paragraphs.label: assumption
